page.title: 18HISTORIC HOUSES OF NEWICK
page.content: Many of the old homes and farmhouses of Newick have been bought by wealthy people and restored to a very high standard.'Gentrification'has taken place - as one local put it.The oldest house in this area is Founthill, built in the 13th century - once a single- storeyed, timber-framed house with a thatched roof. Houses built in the 16th century were Bretts, Ketches, Church Farm (now Manor House), Mackerells and Goldbridge Farm. Shortly after this came Gypps, Tile House, Ridgelands, Sharpsbridge, Rotherfield, Snells and Cuttings (the old Tudor workhouse). Other grand old houses are The Old Rectory and Beechlands. Many of these houses are to be found near the Church, in'Newick proper', as opposed to 'Newick Green', as the two areas were once known.
